_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Compressors, glycol dehydrator, Joule Thompson skid, Flash separator, Horizontal Filter, Storage tanks

_exec_summary.SummaryText: Range Resources Appalachia, LLC Washington Compressor Station recieves unrefined natural gas from an east and west feed line.  The natural gas is run through three compressors on site and then into process equipment that includes, a three stage seperator, a glycol dehydrator, a Joule-Thompson skid and a flash separator.  Natural gas liquids (NGL) are separated from the incoming field gas and is collected and stored in two co-located 30,000 gallon horizontal tanks with a secondary containment wall.  The two 30,000 gallon (NGL) tanks are the main hazardwhen considering off site consequences.  The contents of the NGL is 18.28% propane, 24.59% Butane, 7.32% Iso-butane, and 49.81% Pentane plus longer chain hydrocarbons.  The tanks are chilled and under pressure.  At atmospheric conditions the contents of the tanks would become a gas so that the opportunity for a vapor cloud explosion is possible if there was a rapid depressurization of the tanks.   A management system comparable to OSHA's PSM and containing the 12 elements listed in Program 3 of the EPA Risk Management Program has been written.  A written facility emergency response plan has been developed and employees are trained in the procedures in the plan.  Emergency response arrangements have been made with the Weavertown Environmental Group for spill response and TEAM Industrial Services, Inc. for pipeline emergencies.                                                                                                                                                                        Ralph Tijerina is the EHS Manager for Range Resources Appalachia, LLC and is the company representative responsible for the implementation of the EHS programs and plans.  Various employees and contractors at Range Resources facility are potentially exposed to hazardous chemical and physical agents while performing their normal work assignments.  To recognize, assess, and control exposures of such agents, and include training, Range Re

town Environmental Group, based in Carnegie, PA,  is on retainer for emergency spill response and TEAM Industrial Services, with an office in Pittsburgh, PA is on retainer for pipeline emergencies.  A written emergency response plan is on site at the compressor station and employees have received training in the procedures.  Emergency numbers are posted and arrangements have been made with the Mount Pleasant Township Fire Department, The Hickory Police, Ambulance services with Fort Cherry Ambulance, and five area hospitals.  Procedures for public notification are in place and alarm systems are available for employees at the facility.  The programs in place are in a state of continual improvement and re-evaluation and will follow the guidelines in OSHA Process Safety Management Program.

sources has adopted an Industrial Hygiene Management Plan (IHMP).  The objectives of the IHMP are to protect employee health, determine chemical/physical agents being used and employee's exposure levels to those agents, control exposures, and minimize risk.  Major elements of the plan include a hazard communication (HAZCOM) program, a personal protective equipmnt (PPE) program, respiratory protection program, bloodborne pathogens exposure control program, lead compliance program and benzene policy.                                                                                                                                                                                  The primary process at the facility is the refinement and separation of hydrocarbons to produce natural gas for sales.  The facility has the ability to store 60,000 gallons of natural gas liquids, a 2,100 gallon tank of methanol and five 300 gallon tanks of methanol hydrate inhibitor, three 500 gallon steel double walled tanks of engine oil, and several 55 galon drums of triethylene glycol.                                                                                                                                                                                  The two 30,000 gallon NGL tanks have an automated emergency shutdown in the event of a rapid depressurization which is powered by compressed nitrogen.  Secondary containment is included in storage areas that hold regulated substances.  Relief valves are set to allow excess pressure to escape a vessel at 250 PSI and are included in all of the major process equipement.  A series of check valves and backpressure valves ensure that the gas stream flows in the correct direction in the event of an equipment malfunction.  There have been no accidents at the site.
